review.title: Shallow and Deep Networks Intrusion Detection System: A Taxonomy and Survey
review.abstract: Intrusion detection has attracted a considerable interest from researchers and industries. The community, after many years of research, still faces the problem of building reliable and efficient IDS that are capable of handling large quantities of data, with changing patterns in real time situations. The work presented in this manuscript classifies intrusion detection systems (IDS). Moreover, a taxonomy and survey of shallow and deep networks intrusion detection systems is presented based on previous and current works. This taxonomy and survey reviews machine learning techniques and their performance in detecting anomalies. Feature selection which influences the effectiveness of machine learning (ML) IDS is discussed to explain the role of feature selection in the classification and training phase of ML IDS. Finally, a discussion of the false and true positive alarm rates is presented to help researchers model reliable and efficient machine learning based intrusion detection systems.

sections.heading: 2.1 Classification of Intrusion detection system
sections.text: Different researchers have developed different classification representations. H.Debar et al. [14], S. Axelsson et al. [15], S. Amer et al. [16], C.Xenakis et al. [17], Hung-Ten Lia et al. [18] have previously presented surveys and taxonomies for detecting intrusions. This research builds on their work and introduces deep networking techniques that do not describe all of these referenced works. Given the increasing value of big data, deep networks are an important element for detection in an IDS taxonomy. The taxonomy presented in this paper provides a fine-grained overview of the various machine learning techniques for detecting intrusions, as shown in Figure 2.1. Detection mainly depends on the data source and penetration technique used. The data source are the nodes that collect the information for analysis. The source can be either host or network-based, or both. These two sources are discussed further in section 1.1.

sections.heading: 2.1.1 Host Based IDS (HIDS) Vs. Network Based IDS (NIDS)
sections.text: Host-based IDS were the first type of IDS to be implemented [19]. HIDS are software-based products installed on a host computer that analyze and monitor all traffic activity on the system application files and operating systems [20]. Traffic activity collected by the system application files and systems is referred to as audit trails [22] - [24]. HIDS has the advantage of being able to detect threats from within by scanning traffic activity before it sends and receives data [25]. Its main drawback is that only the host computer is monitored, which means it must be installed on each host [26]. Network-based IDS are found at specific points in the network to detect and analyze the stream of packets passing through network connections, as opposed to HIDS, whose approach is to analyze each host separately [27] [28] [28].

sections.text: I. Ahmad et al. in [133] evaluated SOM, ART and MLP-BP in terms of main criteria and sub-criteria based on analytical hierarchy. The evaluation based on main criteria examined less effort, maturity, competence, performance and suitability. Sub-criteria examined cost effectiveness, time saving, detection rate, minimal false-positive, minimal false-negative, handling of different intruders and coordinated intruder handling. sections.heading: 4.2 Deep Networks
sections.text: This section focuses on networks that look like the Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) but have a different architecture. The difference between the MLP and the Deep Networks is in their training procedures. This is a class of ML techniques in which the classification is done through training data with many layers in hierarchical networks with unattended learning. Deepnetworks are inspired by the architectural depth of the brain. In 2006, Hinton et al. developed Deep Belief Network (DBN) [134] from the University of Toronto. They trained data with an algorithm that greedily trained layer by layer of unattended learning for each layer of the Restricted Boltzmann Machine (RBM) [135]. Following this discovery by Hinton et al., other Deep Networks were successfully introduced according to the same principle in the classification task [136]. Deep Networks IDS can be classified by the way the architectures and techniques are used. Figure 4.3 shows a Deep Networks classification of IDS.

Keywords— Shallow network, Deep networks, Intrusion detection, False positive<lb>alarm rates and True positive alarm rates 1.0 INTRODUCTION<lb>Computer networks have developed rapidly over the years contributing significantly to social<lb>and economic development. International trade, healthcare systems and military capabilities<lb>are examples of human activity that increasingly rely on networks. This has led to an<lb>increasing interest in the security of networks by industry and researchers. The importance of<lb>Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) is critical as networks can become vulnerable to attacks<lb>from both internal and external intruders [1], [2]. An IDS is a detection system put in place to monitor computer networks. These have been in<lb>use since the 1980’s [3].
